data.title: Navigation2D returns same point twice in get_simple_path()
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** 
Linux x64, happens on 2.1.3 **and** latest 3.0.

@godotengine/pr-mergers please cherry picked to 2.1 in case of a PR 


**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
When using `Navigation2D.get_simple_path()` (with the `optimized` argument set to false) the points returned sometimes contains *two* identical points, requiring a workaround to make simple path follow scripts work.

The first position returned is *always* the starting position, but sometimes when the starting position is the same a *previously returned position*, this position will be in the returned point-list **twice**.

A theoretical 1-dimensional example:
You want to go from 0 to 3, the returned points are `[0, 1, 2, 3]`.
Then if you are at **exactly 1** the returned points sometimes are `[1, 1, 2, 3]`.

**Steps to reproduce:**
I included an example project down below with many comments.
The example project is using **3.0**, but I know that this problem exists in 2.1.3 too.

The example projects lets the sprite find the mouse position. <kbd>enter</kbd> toggles the following of the path.

To reproduce without the example project:
 - set up a Navigation2D with NavigationPolygonInstance
 - use `get_simple_path()` on every frame (in practice needed for moving enemies, for example)
 - move along the returned path, only moving towards the next position returned earlier.
 - observe that some points occur multiple times


**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->
[nav_demo.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1221052/nav_demo.zip)

data.title: [2.1.4] Inspector doesn't update when updating selection from plugin
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux, 2.1.4-beta (July 31)

**Issue description:**
When selecting a 2D node with `get_selection().add_node()` from an EditorPlugin, the inspector doesn't update and show the properties of the newly selected node. Additionally, if the new node has some special editor controls, they don't show up. (for example Polygon2D doesn't show its verticies).

data.title: Exposed create_from_mesh in Navmesh
data.body:
Would kinda close #4301

This pull request would allow the creation of navmeshes using a mesh by exposing create_from_mesh in navmesh.

this would make generating navmeshes from code way easier because we could use the surface tool to generate a mesh and then use that mesh to make the navmesh. This would also make it where you're not forced to define the verticies and indicies to generate a mesh, which can be confusing to new users (I only kinda understand how it works because I've looked through the code, and have done some OpenGL before)

I can provide a sample project with generating mazes from code with a navmesh later if desired, which would (probably) fully close #4301

data.title: Adds Engine::is_editor_hint() method
data.body: It's sometimes desired to check this before the main loop is initialized. In my case, I need to check this somewhere in `ScriptLanguage::init()`, in order to know which assemblies to load.

data.title: Implement OrderedHashMap
data.body:
There is a common need to store key-value association while being able to iterate the pairs in insertion order. There are already examples of this in the existing codebase [\[1\]](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/3bea3256f5def126b2b6d639ed70c4ddc3990344/core/io/resource_format_binary.h#L127) [\[2\]](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/3bea3256f5def126b2b6d639ed70c4ddc3990344/core/class_db.h#L141) [\[3\]](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/3bea3256f5def126b2b6d639ed70c4ddc3990344/editor/editor_profiler.h#L79), where either a List or a Vector is separately stored just to allow to iterate keys or values in insertion order. However, it leads to code duplication and clutter and so having a single data structure that allows insertion-based iteration is beneficial.

This PR implements OrderedHashMap that internally stores HashMap and a List for ordering. It'll be used for implementing [ordering of NativeScript properties](https://github.com/endragor/godot/commit/2d7c2aeb2f8d04a783148df432477687f449866a) and can be utilized wherever a data structure with these properties is necessary.

I renamed HashMap's Entry to Element for consistency with other collections APIs. I had to expose it for efficient implementation of OrderedHashMap's `insert` method, and I think later it makes sense to allow to iterate HashMap similarly to Map and make its API more consistent with Map in general.

data.title: KinematicBody2D.get_collision_count() is not working correctly
data.body:
**_bugsquadedit:_** It seems `KinematicBody2D.get_collision_count()` is not working for some reason. It might be somehow related to the fact there is no `KinematicBody2D.is_colliding()` method in 3.0 (not sure why?). Uploading reproduction project below, since original one is not compiling:
[Issue: KinematicBody2D_collision_count().zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1234371/Issue.KinematicBody2D_collision_count.zip)
Tested on 1a92906b681735a5a2acfd98e3d6a4c75a7f6115
edit2: from @novemberist comment it seems it's not working only when used together with `move` (and working with `move_and_slide`)

-----

**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7 64bit - Godot 3.0 alpha1

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
This video shows the bug:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hZOAgQEiuYA
If i press right arrow key, it suppose to make the sprite move right, at the same speed.
but for some reason, the sprite keeps slowing down.
The same code is running fine on the stable ( steam ) version of Godot engine.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Make KinematicBody2D, add a Sprite and a CollisionShape2D as childs.
add to the KinematicBody2D this code: 
``` GDScript
extends KinematicBody2D

const GRAVITY = 16.0
const WALK_SPEED = 20
var velocity = Vector2()
func _ready():
	set_process(true)
	set_fixed_process(true)
	pass
func _process(delta):
	if (Input.is_action_pressed("ui_left")):
		velocity.x = - WALK_SPEED
	elif (Input.is_action_pressed("ui_right")):
		velocity.x =   WALK_SPEED
	else:
		velocity.x = 0
	
func _fixed_process(delta):
	velocity.y += delta * GRAVITY
	var motion = velocity * delta
	motion = move(motion)
	
	if (is_colliding()):
		var n = get_collision_normal()
		motion = n.slide(motion)
		velocity = n.slide(velocity)
		move(motion)
	
```
Save that object. Create new scene, add a new node, and than add this object as his child.
To the root node ( the new node of the scene) add StaticBody2D and add it a CollisionShape2D. 
Than run the scene and press left arrow key or right arrow key and see the sprite slowing down after a while.
**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->
[Slowdown movement bug - godot 3.0 alpha1 project.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1220084/Slowdown.movement.bug.-.godot.3.0.alpha1.project.zip)

data.title: Cant get pixel-perfect on [Godot 3.0 Alpha1]
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7 64bit - 3.0 Alpha1

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
![godot alpha1 error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23245138/29244146-d1c9c086-7fb9-11e7-9391-6874e89a01d9.png)

Well, the picture pretty much says everything. 
The problem is the blurry effect created on low res sprite ( as pixel arts), it isnt sharp as it is suppose to be.
I guess it is happens when sprite's X or Y isnt an integer, i tried setting non-integer ( as 20.3 or 108.6) in the X axis, and the effect happened, while it didnt happen when i set it to interger number ( as 50 or 120).
I tried diffrents project settings, and couldn't fix it. I looked for answer in internet, nope.
I did created the same project on the stable version ( the one on Steam), and it worked as wanted.

**Steps to reproduce:**
In Project Settings, Display -> Window -> [ enter low width and height ( in my project it is 240x160)]
Stretch mode -> 'viewport'
Aspect -> 'Keep'

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->
[Pixel blur bug - godot 3.0 alpha1 project.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1220066/Pixel.blur.bug.-.godot.3.0.alpha1.project.zip)

data.title: Exported int var gets broken when set via randi()
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

Windows 10 64, Godot 2.1.3

**Issue description:**
I'm setting a new exported variable on a node via:
`export(int) var id`
On creation in editor, I'm setting it to a random value with:
`randomize()`
`node.id = randi()`
Later, at runtime, the id is sometimes different than when viewing in the editor, and generally behaves erratically. Crashes with 'shit? No such file or directory', when the filed is interacted with the value jumps in editor etc.

data.title: Debugger gets broken when reading large files
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Ubuntu 17.04
Godot 2.1.3 & Godot 3 (commit a75623f436c215e107ede321afa08a1897552deb)

**Issue description:**
When I try to read a large file using the File class in GDScript the execution seems to work fine. However, if I set a breakpoint after the line `file.get_as_text()` the debugger gets closed and the next message is shown in the console:

`ERROR: put_packet: Condition ' p_buffer_size + 4 > temp_buffer.size() ' is true. returned: ERR_INVALID_PARAMETER
   At: core/io/packet_peer.cpp:220.
ERROR: _notification: Condition ' cmd.get_type() != Variant::STRING ' is true.
   At: editor/script_editor_debugger.cpp:970.`

Note: this output is from Godot 2.1.3. In Godot 3 the output is the same but the highlighted line in `script_editor_debugger.cpp` is 991 rather than 970.

I noticed this when trying to read a large JSON file (see the attached project `test.zip`). I also tried to remove keys from the JSON file (`tile_info.json` in the project) to check if at some point the debugger stops getting broken. And it does. So I assumed the size of the file has something to do with this issue.

I also tried to avoid the conversion from JSON to Dictionary (this isn't the cause of the issue, but I needed a temporal solution to keep working) by creating a Dictionary object straight away in a GDScript file and pasting the content of the JSON there. The behavior is exactly the same: the debugger keeps getting broken. This is not included in the minimal example project and I have tested it only in Godot 2.1.3.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Open the attached project (`test.zip`) with Godot 3.
2. Run the project to check that `tile_info.json` content is printed out correctly.
3. Comment out the line `# breakpoint` and run the project again
4. The debugger doesn't work anymore and the buttons stop responding.

Note: if you remove lines from `tile_info.json` until you've got around 4000 lines everything starts to work fine.

**Link to minimal example project:**
[test.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1219975/test.zip)

data.title: Updated function argument names
data.body:
This pull request along with #10260 fixes #10244.

On some cases I wasn't sure how to name the variables and I ended up picking the most common name I saw within the corresponding header and implementation files.

Feedback is welcome.

data.title: An inner class cannot be extended out of its script file
Add categories to GDScript exported variables
data.body:
Closes #4378 via the 4th proposal, as it is easiest to implement
Supports:
```gdscript
category xyz:
    export var x = 2
category "xyz/test":
    export var y = 5
category(test):
    export var z = 6
category("test/xyz"):
    export var w = 8
export var a = 7 # Would appear before the categorised variables because of limitations
func _ready():
    print(x + y + z + w)
```
Does not yet support:
```gdscript
category a:
    category b:
        export var c = 2
# can be faked using `category "a/b":`
```

But, most of all, needs some extra testing, as I might have broken things.

data.title: Project manager's file system box should be updated to match the ones within projects
data.body:
The "file system" dialog box used when creating/importing a project is pretty barebones compared to the one used within projects:

File system box seen when importing a project within the project manager:
![bad](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27100585/29240704-062e297c-7fae-11e7-8e80-7e8b87b73d74.png)

File system box seen when loading a Sprite node's texture within a project:
![good](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27100585/29240707-0d43d7e8-7fae-11e7-9fb5-3fb74ff06902.png)

The navigation icons at the top-left alone would go a long way towards improving its usability, but I think it could also use things like the darkened background (I expect this will be added down the line anyway), an icon view, and even a favorites panel.
